body: I think that's fine, my concern is that the description for conf currently is `"JSON string that gets pickled into the DagRun's conf attribute"`  , I am not sure user has context  on whether this conf could be used in backfill . I think a proper description would be `JSON string that gets pickled into the DagRun / backfill 's conf attribute`

Cannot simply change `title="{{ current_user.username }}"` to `title="{{ current_user.user.username }}"` because tests will fail. The [AnonymousUserMixin()](https://flask-login.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/flask_login/mixins.html#AnonymousUserMixin) object does not have user attribute while [DefaultUser()](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/1f0a717b65e0ea7e0127708b084baff0697f0946/airflow/default_login.py#L45), [GoogleUser()](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/1f0a717b65e0ea7e0127708b084baff0697f0946/airflow/contrib/auth/backends/google_auth.py#L47), etc have.

@NielsZeilemaker I know, but I looked at the code and I don’t think that makes sense. We are not testing anything inside airflow by it and the tests together would still take around 20seconds.
Well, it verifies this logic: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/hooks/S3_hook.py#L98-L102
No it doesn’t, that part will always be tested as you can see in the test coverage as well. There will be always one page if you have results.

It looks like the branch is still being hit: https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3455/src/airflow/hooks/S3_hook.py#L98...102 

🤔

Yes, logging is still an issue. Now again with the Kubernetes executor we need to rework it again. Would be nice to find a more robust way of logging.
Getting it from the config instead of the environment variable, allows us to have at least one single way of setting the variabele.

It will, as you always have a single page, but testing to see if multiple pages work would have my preference, as I actually encountered this bug while using the hook. Maybe there is a quicker method to add the files?
@hprudent can you squash your commits into a single commit?
@kaxil
@mistercrunch this is the same issue you're experiencing?
cc @NielsZeilemaker 👍
Thanks

@mchalek 

Please resolve the below errors for Py3:

```
======================================================================
18) ERROR: test_failed_operation_detector (tests.contrib.hooks.test_gcp_dataproc_hook.DataProcHookTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
   Traceback (most recent call last):
    tests/contrib/hooks/test_gcp_dataproc_hook.py line 144 in test_failed_operation_detector
      self.assertTrue(context.exception.message.startswith(
   AttributeError: 'Exception' object has no attribute 'message'
```
Can you lower the page size somehow?
@feng-tao Could you please check this BUG: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2558

Sorry about that, @kaxil , I think it should be fixed by my last commit.  I can rebase/force-push that back into the original commit if/when you decide this is ready to merge.

In the comments on the [Jira](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2549), @DanSedov pointed out that this commit addresses an issue they would like to fix in DataProc (by surfacing errors at the top level of the API response).  So it may not be necessary to merge this into Airflow.

I think it would be useful to identify the failed job in the Airflow error message, which is something that this commit accomplishes (we have already found it useful in our deployments at Etsy).  For this to work without this airflow commit, it will be necessary for the DataProc error message to indicate the failed jobs.  @DanSedov can you provide guidance on whether the specific job failures will be surfaced in the top-level API `error` field once your fix is in place?

Folks, facing a strange issue, the spec I wrote is working on my laptop, but not on travis.
```
$ nosetests tests/models.py:DagBagTest.test_kill_zombies
.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.180s

OK
[2018-06-03 22:19:22,250] {settings.py:188} DEBUG - Disposing DB connection pool (PID 98334)
```

It used to work earlier, when I had `job_id` as a param in `__init__` of `TaskInstance`, which I removed and setting it explicitly from the tests. Could Travis is using somekind of DB caching while doing join calls, cause in Rails world its quite common with RSpec.

@NielsZeilemaker @Fokko updated. Page size is a supported setting

Note: @Fokko lets not accept PRs anymore that go over 2s in tests.

I see the same failure as Travis on my laptop:

```
(airflow) (themisto python/incuba…irflow PR_TOOL_MERGE_PR_1796_MASTER:*)% nosetests tests.models:DagBagTest.test_kill_zombies
F
======================================================================
FAIL: Test that kill zombies call TIs failure handler with proper context
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/ash/.virtualenvs/airflow/lib/python3.5/site-packages/mock/mock.py", line 1305, in patched
    return func(*args, **keywargs)
  File "/Users/ash/code/python/incubator-airflow/tests/models.py", line 1420, in test_kill_zombies
    ANY)
  File "/Users/ash/.virtualenvs/airflow/lib/python3.5/site-packages/mock/mock.py", line 925, in assert_called_with
    raise AssertionError('Expected call: %s\nNot called' % (expected,))
AssertionError: Expected call: handle_failure(<ANY>, True, <ANY>)
Not called
```

@Fokko Im not sure what you are on. The xcom stuff is already in and this pr just picks it up. There is nothing special to it.  It is also in line with the discussions on the mailinglist. If you have a suggestion for visualizing differently thats fine?

I don't have an explicit opinion about it, because I don't have a specific use case for it right now. I also missed the discussion on the mailinglist because I've been a bit busy lately. Just being a bit reserved in adding a lot of additional logic around the Airflow core :)

Gotcha. Only 2 calls are made to XCom (inlets, outlet) for every task. If we do think that we will hit performance issues for large dags we can always batch it.
@mchalek I guess we should then wait for the next release which should be in a week. If we would be now receiving the error message in the response itself, do you think we need this PR anymore?

@Fokko I would like to include this in v1.10 as well. But I didn't merge to v1.10-test branch as I read somewhere in dev list emails that we may rebranch 1.10 from master.

>We will rebranch 1.10 from master.
I've moved all global settings from the logging_config to the configuration file and added a section to the upgrading.md.

Given that this is a github *enterprise* auth backend, it's a bit confusing to have code implicitly convert `github.com` to `https://api.github.com` which is GH, not GHE. Why not just set `host=https://api.github.com` in the config file to use this backend for non-enterprise GH auth for your use case.
Seems unrelated. Thanks for the fix. +1
@r39132 Can you take a look at this too?

This is neat. I was traveling when you added this feature so I didn't get around to it until now. A few thoughts:
(1) looking at datasets.py, qualified name could be None. I didn't test it out, but I assume this would render a blank node in the view. perhaps qualified_name should be a required field.
(2) is `auto`'s behavior recursive? if I have A-> B-> C , and B does nothing to the dataset, can I have both B and C inlet set to 'auto', and have C pick up lineage from A? (and maybe this would mean having 'auto' for outlets as well?)
(3) should be able to turn this feature on/off, or generate lineage in a separate view. We don't have a strong use-case for it for now, and I can see a scenario where some of the operators have their inlets/outlets automatically set in the constructor (to save end users from manually setting them). This would result in incomplete lineage views and may be confusing for users who are not familiar with the feature. (ideally, all inlets/outlets should be generated automatically, but that's a lot of effort and require going through each operator, so it'll take some times to get there).

@jgao54 Github uses `github.com` for the oauth calls and  `api.github.com` for the API calls (like fetching user info). This means that if I set `host=https://api.github.com` as you suggest, the oauth requests would fail.
It may be possible to create a new configuration variable like `api_host` or something similar but it seemed a little overkill just for this use case. Please let me know what you think.
